prompts.1: Topic: Computers and Society. Write a letter to your local newspaper stating your opinion on the effects computers have on people.
prompts.2: Topic: Censorship in Libraries. Do you believe that certain materials should be removed from shelves if found offensive?
prompts.3: Topic: 'Rough Road Ahead'. Explain how the features of the setting affect the cyclist.
prompts.4: Topic: 'Winter Hibiscus'. Explain why the author concludes the story with the hibiscus paragraph.
prompts.5: Topic: 'Narciso Rodriguez'. Describe the mood created by the author in the memoir.
prompts.6: Topic: 'The Mooring Mast'. Describe the obstacles the builders faced in allowing dirigibles to dock.
prompts.7: Topic: Patience. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know was patient.
prompts.8: Topic: Laughter. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

source_texts.3:
Title: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit
Author: Joe Kurmaskie
Content Summary: The author describes a cycling trip where he took a 'shortcut' suggested by some old locals. It turned out to be a grueling, hot, and waterless route through the desert. He suffered from dehydration and heat exhaustion.
Key Quote: 'I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face... The road began to rise... The heat became a physical weight.'
source_texts.4:
Title: Winter Hibiscus
Author: Minfong Ho
Content Summary: Saeng, a teenage girl from Vietnam, fails her driver's test. She feels discouraged. Later, she visits a florist and sees a hibiscus plant that reminds her of her home in Vietnam. The plant symbolizes resilience and hope.
Key Quote: 'When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.'
source_texts.5:
Title: Narciso Rodriguez (Memoir)
Author: Narciso Rodriguez
Content Summary: The fashion designer describes his childhood home in Newark, New Jersey. His parents, originally from Cuba, created a warm, traditional home filled with Cuban music and cooking. He emphasizes that 'family' is about community and love, not just blood relations.
source_texts.6:
Title: The Mooring Mast (Empire State Building)
Author: Marcia Amidon LÃ¼sted
Content Summary: Describes the construction of the Empire State Building. To beat the Chrysler Building in height, Al Smith added a 'mooring mast' for dirigibles (airships) to the top. However, docking airships proved dangerous and impractical due to high winds and updrafts.
